content:
The Act titled "Two Floods and You Are Out of the Taxpayers' Pocket Act of 1999" aims to reduce flood losses for repetitive flood insurance claim properties. The National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 is amended to prioritize properties with repetitive flood insurance claim payments for mitigation activities. This amendment also addresses properties in areas with repetitive flood insurance claim payments. The Director has the authority to waive dollar amount limitations for states or communities during major disasters. The National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 is amended to prioritize properties with repetitive flood insurance claim payments for mitigation activities, with funding not exceeding $70,000,000 annually. The Director can waive dollar amount limitations during declared disasters. The National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 is amended to prioritize properties with repetitive flood insurance claim payments for mitigation activities, with funding not exceeding $50,000,000 annually. SEC. 4. CONSOLIDATION OF AUTHORIZATIONS. The National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 is amended to adjust borrowing authority, contracts, emergency implementation, and authorization of appropriations for studies. The National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 is amended to adjust borrowing authority, contracts, emergency implementation, and authorization of appropriations for studies. Section 1376(c) (42 U.S.C. 4127(c)) is modified to specify the end date as mentioned in section 1319. SEC. 5. CHARGEABLE PREMIUM RATES. The amendment to Section 1308 of the National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 establishes actuarial rate properties, ensuring that the chargeable rate for certain properties is not less than the estimated risk premium rate. This applies to post-firm properties constructed or substantially improved after specific dates. The chargeable rate for properties under this paragraph is subject to the limitation under subsection (e). It includes properties with repetitive flood insurance claim payments and owners who refuse buyouts or mitigation measures funded by FEMA, as well as certain leased coastal and river properties. The annual limitation on premium increases applies. The annual limitation on premium increases applies to properties described under paragraph (2) or (3) of subsection (c) of the National Flood Insurance Act of 1968. SEC. 6. Removing repetitive claim properties from federal disaster assistance responsibility. Section 582 of the National Flood Insurance Reform Act of 1994 is amended to prevent federal disaster relief assistance from being used for properties with repetitive flood insurance claims. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act offers assistance to property owners affected by flood events, even if they have previously refused it. The amendment applies to disasters declared after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 7. MITIGATION GRANTS FOR REPETITIVE CLAIM PROPERTIES. Amends the National Flood Insurance Act to provide grants for properties with repetitive flood claims. The Director may fund mitigation actions to reduce flood damages for repetitive flood insurance claim properties if it is in the best interest of the National Flood Insurance Fund and cannot be funded under another program due to state or community limitations. Availability of National Flood Insurance Fund amounts is amended. The Director may fund mitigation actions for repetitive flood insurance claim properties if in the best interest of the National Flood Insurance Fund and cannot be funded under another program due to state or community limitations. Availability of National Flood Insurance Fund amounts is amended to include funding for mitigation actions under section 1323. SEC. 8. USE RESTRICTIONS ON ACQUIRED PROPERTY.

Amends the National Flood Insurance Act to restrict the use of acquired properties to ensure they are maintained for open space, recreational, or wetlands management practices.

SEC. 9. DEFINITION OF REPETITIVE CLAIM PROPERTIES. SEC. 9 amends the National Flood Insurance Act to define 'repetitive flood insurance claim payments' as multiple claim payments for property losses under flood insurance coverage, regardless of payment amount, timing, or property ownership.
